doc.source_uri: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.2 普通个人版/Nomura/Asia Insights - China August manufacturing PMI shows continued softnessAsia Insights - China August manufacturing PMI sh_2025-08-31

processing_metadata.publication: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.2 普通个人版/Nomura
processing_metadata.input_relative_path: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.2 普通个人版/Nomura

passages.text: Economics - Asia ex- Japan

The official manufacturing PMI remained subdued at 49.4 in August, increasing marginally from 49.3 in July and broadly in line with consensus (Consensus: 49.5; Nomura: 49.3). The non- manufacturing PMI edged up to 50.3 in August from 50.1 in July, slightly above consensus (Consensus: 50.2; Nomura: 50.0). Despite the marginal rise, the manufacturing PMI has remained below 50 for five months since the tariff blitz in April, with persistent weakness in new export orders. Meanwhile, the continued rise in the price indices reflects the intensifying campaign against low- price competition, which could dampen investment and output activity. The improvement in the non- manufacturing PMI was primarily driven by capital market services, buoyed by the recent stock market rally, while retail sales and property sectors have remained a drag.

The subdued manufacturing PMI points to continued weak growth momentum on various fronts. While the stock market rally has gained momentum, its spillover effects on the real economy may be limited, as household wealth is still concentrated in property, and financial sector compensation remains largely capped. The rising growth headwinds call for more policy support, but deploying pro- growth measures might risk causing a stock market bubble. In our view, Beijing's best strategy is to draw lessons from the past, resist the temptation to fuel the stock markets by avoiding too high- profile monetary measures in the near term, remain vigilant by avoiding contractionary policies, clean up the property mess, and address some deep- rooted problems, such as the unequal social security system.
The official manufacturing PMI stayed weak at 49.4 in August (Consensus: 49.5; Nomura: 49.3), following a notable decline to 49.3 in July from 49.7 in June.

Most of sub- indices increased in August. Production and raw materials inventory picked up most, rising to 50.8 and 48.0, respectively, in August from 50.5 and 47.7 in July. New orders and new export orders sub- indices both inched up in August, rising marginally to 49.5 and 47.2, respectively, from 49.4 and 47.1 in July, while employment edged down to 47.9 from 48.0. Suppliers' delivery efficiency, an inverted sub- index to the headline index, rose to 50.5 in August from 50.3 in July.

Amid the anti- involution campaign, prices of raw materials have increased further. Input and output price indices increased to 53.3 and 49.1, respectively, in August from 51.5 and 48.3 in July. The rising raw material price indices are in line with our forecast for PPI inflation of \(0.1\%\) m- o- m in August, rising from \(- 0.2\%\) in July (see China monthly: August data preview, 29 August 2025).

The PMI pattern for firms of different sizes reversed in August from July. The PMI for large and small firms rebounded to 50.8 and 46.6, respectively, in August, following the drop to 50.3 and 46.4 in July from 51.3 and 47.3 in June, while the PMI for medium- sized firms dropped to 48.9 in August, following an increase to 49.5 in July from 48.6 in June.

The official non- manufacturing PMI increased modestly to 50.3 in August from 50.1 in July, above both market expectations and our forecasts (Consensus: 50.2 and Nomura: 50.0), with the construction sector remaining a major drag. The services PMI increased moderately to 50.5 in August from 50.1 in July, the highest reading so far this year.

From an industry perspective, the business activity indices for capital market services, railway transport, aviation transport, and telecommunications broadcasting television and satellite transmission services all remained in the high prosperity zone above 60.0, with relatively rapid growth in total business volume. Among these, the business activity index for capital market services has remained above 70.0 for two consecutive months,

according to the NBS. We believe this is largely due to the recent rally in onshore equity markets (see China: Policymaking amid a stock market rally and growth slowdown, 21 August 2025). Nevertheless, the business activity indices for retail, property, and other industries all fell below the critical level of 50, indicating relatively weak activity.

The construction PMI fell sharply again to 49.1 in August from 50.6 in July, reaching its lowest point since the onset of the Covid pandemic in early 2020. The significant pullback in the construction PMI at a minimum was partly owing to adverse weather conditions in August, as the NBS claimed again – similar to July – that, due to recent adverse weather factors such as continued high temperatures, heavy rain and flooding in some areas, construction work slowed in August. The new order sub- index of construction PMI dropped by more than 2pp to 40.6 in August.

Fig. 2: Major sub-indices of the official manufacturing PMI
Source: Wind, Nomura Global Economics
